claim_reports.claim_text: Over five days, four million Texans lost power during the storm.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that over four million Texans lost power during the storm, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming widespread outages due to severe winter weather.

supports.title: 2021 Texas Power Grid Failure – a preventable disaster - DEITABASE
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that over 4 million Texans lost power during the storm, as widespread outages were reported due to severe winter weather and the inability of the power grid to meet demand.
supports.snippet: In 2021, Winter Storm Uri brought record-breaking low temperatures to the people of Texas, overwhelming the under-designed Texas power grid.

supports.title: ERCOT Blackout 2021 - UT Energy Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during Winter Storm Uri from February 15-18, 2021, a significant number of Texans experienced power outages, with a survey showing that 69 percent of Texans lost power at some point during the storm, which aligns with the claim of four million Texans losing power over five days.

supports.snippet: More than 4.5 million people in Texas lost power – some for as long as four days. Tragically, the loss of electricity caused the deaths of ...

supports.title: The Great Texas Freeze: February 11-20, 2021 | News
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that during Winter Storm Uri, 69 percent of Texans lost power at some point between February 14-20, 2021, with the average disruption lasting 42 hours. This supports the claim that a significant number of Texans experienced power outages during the storm, although it does not specify that four million lost power over five days.
supports.snippet: The Great Freeze lasted 8 days, 23 hours, and 23 minutes, with the last Hard Freeze Warning expiring on Saturday, February 20th at 9 a.m. ...

supports.title: Winter Storm Uri 2021 - Texas Comptroller
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that over 4 million people in Texas lost power during the storm, as stated in the article, which discusses the widespread power outages caused by severe winter weather.
supports.snippet: The UT-Austin report found that Uri, although not the most severe Texas winter storm on record, caused the most loss of electricity.

claim_reports.claim_text: ERCOT reported the state was four minutes away from total grid collapse.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was 4 minutes and 37 seconds away from total collapse during the February 2021 freeze, indicating a critical situation that supports the claim.

supports.title: 2021 Texas Power Grid Failure – a preventable disaster - DEITABASE
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the grid was very close to a total blackout, specifically stating it was 4 minutes and 37 seconds away from a complete statewide blackout.
supports.snippet: ERCOT later revealed that the grid was just 4 minutes and 37 seconds from a complete statewide blackout which could have taken weeks to restore ...

supports.title: Final Report on February 2021 Freeze Underscores Winterization ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT ordered rolling blackouts to prevent grid collapse during the February 2021 freeze, indicating that the state was indeed close to a total grid failure.
supports.snippet: The Texas grid operator (Electric Reliability Council of Texas or ERCOT) ordered a total of 20,000 MW of rolling blackouts in an effort to ...

supports.title: ERCOT's Frequency Drop on February 15th. - ResearchGate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas grid was just 4 minutes and 37 seconds away from a potential total collapse, indicating a critical situation during the frequency drop.
supports.snippet: On the morning of February 15, the Texas grid's frequency declined to below 59.4 Hz for four minutes and 23 seconds.

supports.title: How has Texas' power grid improved 1 year after near-collapse?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was indeed four minutes and 37 seconds away from total collapse during the events of February 15, 2021.
supports.snippet: On Feb. 15, 2021, the Texas power grid was four minutes and 37 seconds away from completely collapsing, an event that would have triggered a ...

supports.title: Texas was minutes away from monthslong power outages, officials say
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ERCOT reported the Texas power grid was just 4 minutes and 37 seconds away from a cascading failure that could have resulted in prolonged power outages across the state.

claim_reports.claim_text: Since 2006, Texas has subsidized renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The claim that Texas has subsidized renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion since 2006 is refuted by multiple high-reliability sources, including a PolitiFact article and a report from the Statesman, both stating that Texas has not provided such a level of subsidies. While one source mentions $19 billion in subsidies from 2007 to 2016, it does not confirm the total since 2006, indicating a discrepancy.

refutes.title: No, Texas didn't hand out $19 billion in wind subsidies
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence refutes the claim by stating that Texas has not provided $19 billion in taxpayer subsidies to wind energy companies since 2006, as asserted by Allen West.
refutes.snippet: Allen West: “Since 2006 Texas has given $19B in taxpayer subsidies to wind energy companies. · PolitiFact's ruling: False · Here's why: ...

refutes.title: No, Texas has not given $19 billion in wind subsidies - PolitiFact
refutes.evidence_summary: The article argues that Texas has not actually provided $19 billion in subsidies to wind energy, suggesting that the claim is exaggerated or misleading.
refutes.snippet: "Since 2006 Texas has given $19B in taxpayer subsidies to wind energy companies. Over the past 2-3 years Texas has tripled our dependence on ...

refutes.title: The Government-Imposed Cost of Electricity in Texas
refutes.evidence_summary: The article discusses Texas's energy subsidies, noting that renewable energy subsidies totaled $4 billion in 2023, but does not confirm the total of $19 billion since 2006, suggesting a discrepancy in the claim.
refutes.snippet: Figure 3 shows that renewable subsidies totaled $4 billion in 2023, but the other government-imposed costs, $15.9 billion, were almost four ...

supports.snippet: ... $19 billion from 2007 to 2016. In Texas, the PTC is one among many subsidies that benefit renewable energy generators. Our research suggests ...

mixed.snippet: State lawmakers have pushed bills to support fossil fuel-burning power plants and restrict renewable energy development this legislative session.

claim_reports.claim_text: The temperature in Texas dropped below zero during Valentine's week 2021.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that Texas experienced extremely low temperatures during Valentine's week in 2021, with an average temperature of 11.8°F on February 15, indicating that temperatures dropped below freezing and likely below zero in some areas.

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that Texas experienced extremely low temperatures during Valentine's week in 2021, with an average temperature of 11.8°F on February 15, and many areas seeing temperatures significantly below normal, suggesting that some locations likely dropped below zero.
supports.snippet: Austin received more than six inches of snow, nearly an inch of ice from freezing rain, and consecutive days of below-freezing temperatures. Statewide supply ...

supports.title: When the historic February 2021 winter storm hit San Antonio - KSAT

supports.snippet: 107.5 hours below 33 degrees: From Feb. 12 to early Feb. 17, 2021, San Antonio endured temperatures below freezing for an extended period.

claim_reports.claim_text: Texas's economy grew by 35% from 2010 to 2020.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents mixed signals regarding Texas's economic growth from 2010 to 2020. While sources like the Statista article and the Baker Institute discuss significant growth in oil production and tax revenues, they do not provide a specific percentage confirming the 35% claim. The FRED data also highlights economic performance but lacks a definitive growth figure. Therefore, while there is evidence of growth, it does not conclusively support the 35% figure.

mixed.title: U.S. annual GDP growth in Texas 2000-2023 - Statista
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses Texas's economic growth, particularly highlighting the significant increase in oil production tax revenues since 2010, which has contributed to the state's overall economic growth. However, it does not provide a specific percentage for the overall economic growth from 2010 to 2020, making it unclear if the 35% claim is accurate.
mixed.snippet: In 2023, the real gross domestic product (GDP) of Texas increased by roughly *** percent compared to the previous year.

mixed.title: After Decades of Growth, Texas Revenues Plateau - Baker Institute
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses Texas's economic growth, particularly in sales tax revenues and oil production taxes, but does not provide a specific percentage growth figure for the overall economy from 2010 to 2020. It mentions that nominal revenues grew at an average annual rate of 6.0%, but real growth was only 3.5%, indicating that while there was growth, it may not align with the 35% claim.
mixed.snippet: After decades of growth, Texas' revenues are plateauing. What's driving the slowdown in sales taxes, oil and gas collections, and federal ...

mixed.title: Gross Domestic Product: All Industry Total in Texas (TXNGSP) - FRED
mixed.evidence_summary: The article discusses Texas's economic growth, particularly highlighting the significant increase in oil production tax revenues since 2010, which suggests a strong economic performance during that period. However, it does not provide a specific percentage growth for the overall economy from 2010 to 2020, making it difficult to confirm the exact claim of a 35% growth.

Multiple reliable sources confirm that at least 246 deaths were attributed to the February 2021 winter storm in Texas, and specifically mention the tragic case of Cristian Pineda, an 11-year-old boy who died in his home during the power outage.

transcript_data.text: The week of Valentine's Day 2021, the temperature dropped below zero. Nobody could remember it being this cold for this long. This was Texas, not Siberia. But Texas is the energy state. There was nothing to fear. Just go home, turn on the heat, and hunker down. That's how it should have gone. Instead, over five days, four million Texans lost power during what turned out to be the coldest winter storm in a half a century. Hundreds died, including an 11-year-old boy who froze to death in his sleep. The state's electric grid operator, the Electric Reliability Council of Texas, ERCOT, later reported the state was just four minutes away from total grid collapse. The media was quick to blame the state government for not being fully prepared and not acting fast enough. This may be true, but ERCOT's mistakes were symptoms, not the cause, of the problem. The real cause is decades of misguided policies that have left the Lone Star state with an unreliable energy infrastructure. It's a cautionary tale that the rest of the country needs to learn from. From 2010 to 2020, the population of Texas increased by 4 million people, and the state's economy grew by 35%. But while all this growth was happening, the state's reliable energy capacity was actually shrinking. Meanwhile, its unreliable energy capacity was surging. In fact, it almost tripled. Let's break this down. Reliable energy is fossil fuels—coal and natural gas—and nuclear. These fuels produce a near-constant flow of electricity. Unreliable, or variable energy, is renewable energy—wind and solar. They're unreliable because they depend on the whims of Mother Nature. In 2020, Texans got 25% of their energy from renewables. During the February storm, however, that fell to 8%, at one point reaching a deadly low of just 1.5%. The reason? Renewable energy only works when the weather cooperates, but it's useless when it doesn't—like when it conjures up a giant snowstorm. Solar panels don't capture sunlight and wind turbines don't spin when covered in snow and ice. Given renewables' unreliability, how is it that Texas, of all places, became so dependent on them? That story begins in 1999, when Texas politicians on the left and the right fell in love with the idea that they could turn the state into a green energy powerhouse. It sounded like a great idea at the time: Instead of passing any new mandates, they would do it by offering massive subsidies, marketed as "incentives," to produce wind and solar power. This ended up working out great for the wind and solar companies, but not so great for reliable energy providers. To illustrate this, imagine that you own a restaurant. One day you learn that your competitor down the street is getting government support. He gets so much help that, instead of charging his customers, he can pay them to eat his food. Not surprisingly, your customers abandon your restaurant for his. Your competitor prospers off the taxpayers' backs while your business withers. Let's apply this analogy to the real world of renewable energy. Wind and solar get so much in subsidies they're guaranteed a profit. And unlike fossil fuel producers, they're not even required to provide reliable power. It's no wonder fossil fuel plants are closing, and nuclear plants are not being built. The wind and solar companies are protected from the laws of supply and demand. They can't lose, and the fossil fuel plants can't compete. That's how out of whack the Texas electricity market has become. Since 2006, the state has subsidized renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion. All of this came right out of Texans' wallets, courtesy of ever-increasing electric bills and rising property taxes. And what does Texas have to show for it? An electric grid that failed when Texans needed it most. Unfortunately, this scenario is playing out across America. Over the past decade, the federal government has spent over $230 billion on energy subsidies, and that doesn't even include subsidies the states give away. It's true that Uncle Sam also grants favors to fossil fuel companies. Renewable energy advocates love to point this out, but here's what they neglect to mention: compared to fossil fuel companies, for every unit of electricity generated, Washington subsidizes wind 17 times and solar 75 times more. Yet, despite all this aid, renewables provide just 4 percent of the country's total energy supply. The verdict is in: renewable energy is expensive and unreliable. And if it can render America's leading power producer powerless, it can do the same to your state. Government meddling got us into this mess. It's time for politicians to step aside and let the free market get us out of it. I'm Jason Isaac from the Texas Public Policy Foundation, for Prager University.

segments.text:
The week of Valentine's Day 2021, 
the temperature dropped below zero.

Nobody could remember it 
being this cold for this long.
This was Texas, not Siberia.

But Texas is the energy state. There 
was nothing to fear. Just go home,
turn on the heat, and hunker down.
That's how it should have gone.

Instead, over five days, four million 
Texans lost power during what turned

out to be the coldest winter storm 
in a half a century. Hundreds died,

including an 11-year-old boy 
who froze to death in his sleep.

The state's electric grid operator, the 
Electric Reliability Council of Texas,

ERCOT, later reported the state was just 
four minutes away from total grid collapse.
The media was quick to blame the state government

for not being fully prepared 
and not acting fast enough.

This may be true, but ERCOT's mistakes were 
symptoms, not the cause, of the problem.

The real cause is decades of 
misguided policies that have

left the Lone Star state with an 
unreliable energy infrastructure.

It's a cautionary tale that the rest 
of the country needs to learn from.

From 2010 to 2020, the population of 
Texas increased by 4 million people,

and the state's economy grew by 35%. But 
while all this growth was happening,

the state's reliable energy 
capacity was actually shrinking.

Meanwhile, its unreliable energy capacity 
was surging. In fact, it almost tripled.
Let's break this down.

Reliable energy is fossil fuels—coal and 
natural gas—and nuclear. These fuels produce

a near-constant flow of electricity. Unreliable, 
or variable energy, is renewable energy—wind and

solar. They're unreliable because they 
depend on the whims of Mother Nature.

In 2020, Texans got 25% of their energy 
from renewables. During the February storm,

however, that fell to 8%, at one point 
reaching a deadly low of just 1.5%.

The reason? Renewable energy only 
works when the weather cooperates,

but it's useless when it doesn't—like 
when it conjures up a giant snowstorm.

Solar panels don't capture sunlight and wind 
turbines don't spin when covered in snow and ice.

Given renewables' unreliability, how is it that 
Texas, of all places, became so dependent on them?

That story begins in 1999, when Texas politicians 
on the left and the right fell in love with the

idea that they could turn the state into a green 
energy powerhouse. It sounded like a great idea

at the time: Instead of passing any new mandates, 
they would do it by offering massive subsidies,

marketed as "incentives," to produce wind 
and solar power. This ended up working

out great for the wind and solar companies, but 
not so great for reliable energy providers.

To illustrate this, imagine that you own a 
restaurant. One day you learn that your competitor

down the street is getting government support. 
He gets so much help that, instead of charging

his customers, he can pay them to eat his food. 
Not surprisingly, your customers abandon your

restaurant for his. Your competitor prospers off 
the taxpayers' backs while your business withers.

Let's apply this analogy to the 
real world of renewable energy.

Wind and solar get so much in 
subsidies they're guaranteed a profit.

And unlike fossil fuel producers, they're 
not even required to provide reliable power.

It's no wonder fossil fuel plants are closing, 
and nuclear plants are not being built.

The wind and solar companies are protected 
from the laws of supply and demand.
They can't lose, and the fossil fuel plants

can't compete. That's how out of whack 
the Texas electricity market has become.

Since 2006, the state has subsidized 
renewable energy to the tune of $19 billion.

All of this came right out of Texans' wallets, 
courtesy of ever-increasing electric bills

and rising property taxes. And what 
does Texas have to show for it?

An electric grid that failed 
when Texans needed it most.

Unfortunately, this scenario 
is playing out across America.

Over the past decade, the federal government 
has spent over $230 billion on energy subsidies,

and that doesn't even include 
subsidies the states give away.

It's true that Uncle Sam also grants 
favors to fossil fuel companies.

Renewable energy advocates love to point this 
out, but here's what they neglect to mention:

compared to fossil fuel companies, for 
every unit of electricity generated,

Washington subsidizes wind 17 
times and solar 75 times more.

Yet, despite all this aid, renewables provide just 
4 percent of the country's total energy supply.

The verdict is in: renewable energy 
is expensive and unreliable. And if

it can render America's leading power producer 
powerless, it can do the same to your state.

Government meddling got us into this mess. 
It's time for politicians to step aside
and let the free market get us out of it.

I'm Jason Isaac from the Texas Public 
Policy Foundation, for Prager University.
